TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant is a civil engineer and building contractor . The present case concerns proceedings brought by the applicant for payment of the balance due for work done under a public works contract .
On DATE ORG ( ORG ) allowed his claim and determined the amounts to be paid him by the treasury of the LOC prefecture ( judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
On DATE the LOC prefecture appealed on points of law .

On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal as being out of time ( judgment no . CARDINAL ) . Judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL then became final . However , despite the steps taken by the applicant the authorities have not yet paid him the sums due .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE regulating certain cases to which the PERSON on ORG relates used to contain the following provision :

“ Enforcement of judicial decisions ( of civil or criminal courts , ORG and ORG ) whereby the ORG is ordered to pay a debt or legal costs shall be prohibited , as shall that of any authority to execute by which the ORG must pay such a debt .
Service of a demand for payment of such debts shall be prohibited and if it is effected nonetheless , such service shall in no way bind the ORG . ”
ORG had ruled that section CARDINAL of Law no . ORG was consistent with LAW and the Convention ( judgment no . CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , at its tenth plenary session on DATE , ORG held that , in the light of LAW , it should be possible to bring enforcement proceedings against the ORG as well .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW , as amended following the constitutional reform of DATE , now provides :
“ ... Judicial decisions shall also be enforceable against the ORG , local authorities and public - law entities ... ”

In a recent judgment ORG , sitting in plenary session , held that section CARDINAL of Law no . ORG ran counter to LAW and that it should be regarded as having been repealed , particularly since the constitutional reform of DATE .
